data.question: Can you provide practice problems on multiplying two matrices?

docs.title: 674dcdb4b00b977d048c931b
docs.text: The admission tickets to the Singapore Zoo are $50 for an adult, $36 for a child, and $20 for a senior citizen. On a particular Tuesday, there were 212 adults, 251 children, and 15 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo and on a particular Wednesday, there were 231 adults, 266 children, and 12 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo. The number of visitors on the particular Tuesday and Wednesday can be represented by the matrix V = \begin{pmatrix} 212 & 251 & 15 \\ 231 & 266 & 12 \end{pmatrix}. \text{ (i) Write a } 3 \times 1 \text{ matrix, P, to represent the price of the admission tickets. (ii) Find the matrix } T = VP. \text{ (iii) Explain what each of the elements represents. (iv) Find the total amount collected from the sales of the tickets for the 2 days.}

docs.title: 674dcde1b00b977d048c9352
docs.text: Two outlets of a coffee chain sell three different types of coffee: espresso, flat white and mocha. The table shows the number of cups of each type of coffee sold on a particular day. Outlet A: Espresso 30, Flat White 30, Mocha 35; Outlet B: Espresso x, Flat White x + 2, Mocha 40. This information can be represented by the matrix \( P = \begin{pmatrix} 30 & 30 & 35 \\ x & x+2 & 40 \end{pmatrix} \). The coffee chain sells a cup of espresso at $2.50, a cup of flat white at $4 and a cup of mocha at $5.50. This information can be represented by the matrix \( Q = \begin{pmatrix} 2.5 \\ 4 \\ 5.5 \end{pmatrix} \). (a) Find, in terms of x, the matrix \( R = PQ \).

docs.title: 674dce0fb00b977d048c9395
docs.text: (c) Evaluate the matrix G = LC.

docs.title: 674dce10b00b977d048c9397
docs.text: (e) The dance school wants to attract more students, so in the next 10-week block, the dance school reduces the price for cultural and international dance sessions by 10%. For this block of sessions, on weekdays, there are 5 cultural dance students and 12 international dance students. On weekends, there are 8 cultural dance students and 15 international dance students. By using matrix multiplication, calculate the total amount of money the dance school earns for this 10-week block of sessions.

docs.title: 674dce93b00b977d048c93d2

docs.title: 674dce1ab00b977d048c93a4
docs.text: Jane exchanged 500 Singapore dollars ($) into Thai baht (THB) when the exchange rate was $1 = 26.77 THB. She travelled to Thailand and spent 10,600 THB. On her return to Singapore, she exchanged the remaining Thai baht into dollars with the exchange rate $1 = 26.88 THB. Calculate the amount she received in dollars. Correct your answer to the nearest cent.

data.output: A cinema complex has two halls, Hall A and Hall B. On a particular Saturday, the number of adult, child, and senior tickets sold in Hall A were 120, 95, and 30 respectively, while in Hall B, the numbers were 135, 140, and 25 respectively. On the following Sunday, the tickets sold were as follows: Hall A - 145 adults, 120 children, and 20 seniors; Hall B - 150 adults, 130 children, and 18 seniors. Represent the ticket sales over these two days by the matrix \( M = \begin{pmatrix} 120 & 95 & 30 & 135 & 140 & 25 \\ 145 & 120 & 20 & 150 & 130 & 18 \end{pmatrix} \). (i) Write a 3 \times 1 matrix, \( C \), representing the costs: $12 for adults, $8 for children, and $6 for seniors. (ii) Find the matrix \( T = MC \). (iii) Explain what each of the elements of matrix \( T \) represents. (iv) Determine the total revenue from ticket sales for both days.

data.output: A theme park has different ticket prices depending on the time of visit: Normal hours - $60 for adults, $40 for children, and $30 for seniors; Peak hours - $75 for adults, $50 for children, and $35 for seniors. In one week, during normal hours, there were 300 adults, 420 children, and 50 seniors, while during peak hours, there were 410 adults, 525 children, and 70 seniors. Represent the number of visitors during normal and peak hours with the matrix \( N = \begin{pmatrix} 300 & 420 & 50 \\ 410 & 525 & 70 \end{pmatrix} \). (i) Write a 3 \( \times \) 1 matrix, P, to represent the normal hours prices. (ii) Write a 3 \( \times \) 1 matrix, Q, to represent the peak hours prices. (iii) Find the matrices \( T_N = NP \) and \( T_P = NQ \). (iv) Interpret each element in the resultant matrices. (v) Find the total revenue collected from ticket sales during the entire week.

data.output:
An art gallery records the sales of two types of art pieces - paintings and sculptures - across two different exhibitions. The table shows the number of each type of art sold. Exhibition X: Paintings 23, Sculptures 11; Exhibition Y: Paintings 30, Sculptures 15. This information can be represented by the matrix \( N = \begin{pmatrix} 23 & 11 \\ 30 & 15 \end{pmatrix} \). The gallery sells a painting for $300 and a sculpture for $450. Represent this pricing as the matrix \( M = \begin{pmatrix} 300 \\ 450 \end{pmatrix} \). 

(a) Calculate the matrix \( S = NM \). 
(b) Describe what each element in the resulting matrix \( S \) signifies. 
(c) Determine the total revenue generated from both exhibitions by the end of these two events.

On a Monday, 190 adults, 220 children, and 10 seniors visited the park, while on a Friday, 205 adults, 240 children, and 18 seniors attended. The visitor data can be expressed as the matrix \( W = \begin{pmatrix} 190 & 220 & 10 \\ 205 & 240 & 18 \end{pmatrix} \). The ticket prices are $45 for an adult, $28 for a child, and $15 for a senior, represented by the matrix \( Q = \begin{pmatrix} 45 \\ 28 \\ 15 \end{pmatrix} \). (i) Find the matrix \( Y = WQ \). (ii) Describe what each element in \( Y \) represents. (iii) Calculate the total revenue from ticket sales over the two days.
